questions.text: When a patient opens their eyes after keeping them closed, which EEG wave activity decreases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alpha waves (8-13 Hz) are rhythmic waves seen most prominently in the occipital region when an adult is awake, relaxed, and with eyes closed

  • Upon eye opening(or during mental activity/attention), alpha waves are suppressed and replaced by low-voltage, asynchronous beta waves (>14 Hz)
  • This phenomenon is called 'alpha block' or 'desynchronisation.'
  • Beta waves (>14 Hz, usually 14-30 Hz):Low voltage, asynchronous, increase with eye opening, attention, mental activity. (Option C)
  • Theta waves (4-7 Hz):Normally in children; in adults during drowsiness, light sleep (NREM stage 1), or emotional stress. (Option B)
  • Delta waves (<4 Hz):High amplitude, slow waves; seen in deep sleep (NREM stages 3-4) or in pathological brain disease. (Option D)

Order of Waves in Sleep:

  • Awake (relaxed, eyes closed):Alpha waves.
  • Awake (alert/eyes open):Beta waves.
  • Stage N1 (light sleep):Theta waves.
  • Stage N2 (intermediate sleep):Theta waves + sleep spindles (12-14 Hz bursts) and K-complexes.
  • Stage N3 (deep/slow-wave sleep):Delta waves predominate.
  • REM sleep:Low-voltage, mixed-frequency activity resembling beta (paradoxical sleep).

So, the progression is: Alpha → Theta (N1) → Theta with spindles/K-complexes (N2) → Delta (N3) → REM (beta-like).

Key Takeaway:

Alpha waves disappear when eyes open and are replaced by beta waves, a hallmark of cortical activation.

questions.text: In which part of the cell are tight junctions located?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tight junctions (zonula occludens) are located at the apicolateral region of epithelial cells, just beneath the apical surface.

  • They form a continuous belt-like structure encircling the cell, preventing free diffusion of membrane proteins between the apical and basolateral surfaces and thereby maintaining cell polarity.
  • Tight junctions also regulate the paracellular pathway, allowing controlled passage of ions, solutes, and water between cells.
  • They are composed mainly of occludin, claudins, and junctional adhesion molecules.

Explanation of other options:

Apical (Option A):

  • Refers to the uppermost surface of the cell facing the lumen.
  • Tight junctions (zonula occludens)are located at the apicolateral border, sealing the space between cells and preventing paracellular transport.
  • Other features:Microvilli, cilia, secretory vesicles.

Basal (Option C):

  • Refers to the bottom surface of the cell resting on the basement membrane.
  • Site of hemidesmosomes and focal adhesions, anchoring the cell to the extracellular matrix.
  • CAMs involved:Integrins (connect cytoskeleton to ECM), dystroglycans.

Basolateral (Option D):

  • Includes the sides and base of the cell.
  • Contains adherens junctions (zonula adherens), desmosomes (macula adherens), and gap junctions (communicating junctions).
  • CAMs involved:
    • Cadherinsin adherens junctions and desmosomes (Ca²⁺-dependent cell–cell adhesion).
    • Connexinsin gap junctions (allow intercellular communication).
    • Integrinsmay also be present at basal-lateral interfaces for ECM interaction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tight junctions = Zonula occludens = Apicolateral.
  • Functions: maintain polarity, regulate paracellular transport, form permeability barrier.
  • Protein components: Occludin, Claudins, JAMs.

questions.text: The fever caused during an infection is regulated by which part of the brain:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Temperature regulation is primarily controlled by the preoptic area of the anterior hypothalamus, which acts as the body's thermostat.

  • Pyrogens (bacterial toxins, tissue breakdown products) stimulate immune cells to release cytokines (notably IL-1).
  • IL-1 acts on the hypothalamus by stimulating the synthesis of prostaglandin E₂ (PGE₂), which raises the set point of the thermoregulatory centre, leading to fever.
  • When prostaglandin synthesis is blocked (e.g., by aspirin/NSAIDs), the fever response is reduced or prevented.

Explanation of other options:

Paraventricular nucleus of thalamus (Option A): Involved in autonomic and neuroendocrine control, not temperature regulation.

Dorsal nucleus of thalamus (Option B): Processes sensory input; not related to thermoregulation.

Amygdala (Option C): Regulates emotions and autonomic responses, not fever.

Key Takeaways:

  • Preoptic area of the hypothalamus= thermoregulatory centre controlling fever.
  • IL-1 → PGE₂ → hypothalamus → raised set point → fever.
  • NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin)lower fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text: Among which of the following pulses is based on the Frank–Starling law?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pulsus alternans is characterised by regularly alternating strong and weak pulse amplitudes despite a normal sinus rhythm.

  • It occurs due to alternating stroke volumesresulting from beat-to-beat variation in left ventricular contractility.

This phenomenon is explained by the Frank-Starling mechanism

  • After a weak contraction, more blood remains in the ventricle, leading to a higher end-diastolic volume (EDV) before the next beat.
  • The increased stretch enhances contractile force on the subsequent beat, resulting in a stronger pulse.
  • This cycle repeats, producing alternating strong and weak pulses.
  • It is most often seen in severe left ventricular dysfunctionand advanced heart failure.

Explanation of other options:

Pulsus bisferiens (Option A): A double-peaked pulse in systole, typically seen in aortic regurgitation or combined AS + AR, not related to Frank-Starling law.

Pulsus paradoxus (Option B): An exaggerated fall in systolic BP (>10 mmHg) during inspiration, seen in cardiac tamponade, severe asthma, COPD, and due to ventricular interdependence, not Frank-Starling.

Pulsus parvus (Option D): A small, weak pulse seen in aortic stenosis or low stroke volume states, due to fixed outflow obstruction, not Frank-Starling.

questions.text: While a person rapid ascent to high altitude leads to which acid – base :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At high altitude, low atmospheric PO₂ causes hypoxaemia, which stimulates peripheral chemoreceptors, leading to hyperventilation.

  • Hyperventilation causes excessive CO₂ washout, leading to a fall in PaCO₂ and H⁺ concentration, resulting in respiratory alkalosis.
  • This alkalosis can induce transient hypocalcaemia(due to increased binding of calcium to albumin), predisposing to tetany.
  • Compensation occurs gradually through renal bicarbonate excretionduring acclimatisation.

Explanation of other options:

Metabolic alkalosis (Option B): Occurs in vomiting or diuretic use.

Respiratory acidosis (Option C): Opposite state, seen in hypoventilation (COPD, neuromuscular disease).

Metabolic acidosis (Option D): Seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and renal failure

Key Takeaways:

  • Rapid ascent → hypoxia → hyperventilation → CO₂ washout → respiratory alkalosis.
  • Renal compensation restores acid-base balance over days (acclimatisation).
  • Important clinical correlate: hypocalcaemia due to alkalosis may cause carpopedal spasm/tetany.

questions.text: What is the tetanizing frequency if the muscle contraction period is 40 milliseconds?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tetanizing frequency is the minimum frequency of stimulation required for individual muscle twitches to fuse into a sustained contraction (tetanus).

  • It is approximately the reciprocal of the contraction period.
  • Formula: Tetanizing frequency = 1/Contraction period

Contraction period = 40 ms = 0.04 s.
Tetanizing frequency = 1 / 0.04 = 25 Hz.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tetanizing frequency ≈ 1 ÷ contraction period.
  • Tetanus occurs when stimuli are rapid enough that muscle does not relax between contractions.

questions.text: All the following are mechanisms of action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ADH does not act on the descending loop of Henle.

  • ADH (vasopressin) acts mainly on the collecting ductsby inserting aquaporin-2 channels, thereby increasing water reabsorption and producing concentrated urine. (Option D ruled out)
  • It also increases urea permeabilityin the inner medullary collecting ducts, which helps maintain medullary hyperosmolarity and enhances water reabsorption. (Option A ruled out)
  • ADH also reduces NaCl reabsorption in the thick ascending loop of Henle, indirectly supporting urine concentration.(Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Site of ADH action:Distal tubules & collecting ducts.
  • Main effects:↑ water permeability, ↑ urea reabsorption (inner medullary CD), ↓ NaCl reabsorption (thick ascending limb).
  • No action on the descending limb of Henle(permeable to water but independent of ADH).

questions.text:
Which of the following features are seen in the Bezold–Jarisch reflex?
1.Hypotension
2.Bradycardia
3.Bradypnoea
4.Tachycardia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is triggered by activation of chemosensitive vagal C-fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (ventricles, atria, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary alveolar region).

This leads to a triad of effects:

  • Hypotension (due to vasodilatation) (Option 1 is seen)
  • Bradycardia (due to vagal stimulation) (Option 2 is seen)
  • Transient bradypnoea/apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing (Option 3 is seen)

Substances such as capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine and certain conditions like myocardial ischaemia, reperfusion injury, and vasovagal syncope can elicit this reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a feed-forward mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Feed-forward mechanisms anticipate a change and initiate a response before the variable is significantly altered, unlike feedback systems which act after a deviation has occurred.

  • Temperature regulation involves feed-forward control, where peripheral thermal receptors detect changes in shell temperature and adjust mechanisms (like shivering, sweating, vasodilation, vasoconstriction) in anticipation of changes in core temperature.
  • This allows the body to pre-emptively prevent major fluctuations in internal temperatur

choices.text: Goes from standing to supine position

questions.text: In which of the following processes, surface tension in alveoli is increased?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surface tension in alveoli is governed by the Law of Laplace (P = 2T/r) and the effect of pulmonary surfactant.

  • Alveolar surface tension is determined by the fluid lining the alveoli and the effect of surfactant secreted by type II alveolar cells.
  • During inspiration, alveoli expand and surfactant molecules become more spread out, lowering their concentration at the air-liquid interface.
  • This reduced effectiveness of surfactant leads to a relative increase in surface tension.
  • Conversely, during expiration, alveoli shrink, surfactant molecules are more concentrated, and surface tension decreases, preventing alveolar collapse.(Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Stands from supine position (Option C): This affects lung volumes and perfusion distribution but not directly alveolar surface tension.

Goes from standing to supine position (Option D): Alters functional residual capacity and ventilation-perfusion matching, not surface tension directly.

Key Takeaway:

Law of Laplace Formula: Pressure (P) = 2 × Surface Tension (T) ÷ Radius (r).

  • Implication: The smaller the radius of the alveolus, the greater the pressure needed to keep it open.
  • Without surfactant, Small alveoli would collapse into larger alveoli (atelectasis) due to higher collapsing pressure.
  • With surfactant: Surface tension is reduced more in smaller alveoli (higher surfactant concentration as alveoli shrink), equalising pressures between small and large alveoli → stabilises alveoli.
  • Clinical relevance: In premature infants with surfactant deficiency, alveoli tend to collapse (Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome) because Laplace's law acts unopposed.
